attributes.title: Starbucks Roast Coffee Caffe Latte Grande Supply Chain
attributes.description: This annotated map shows where parts of the Starbucks Roast Coffee are manufactured.
This is where most of the packaging takes place. This includes the cups, cartoons, etc.
attributes.title: [11]Co-Manufacturer

attributes.description: Starbucks was found in Seattle, USA in 1971. This is where most ideas of coffees and other products came from, including the Roast Coffee Caffe Latte Grande.
attributes.title: [1]Headquarters

attributes.description: The milk is put inside custom made Starbucks paper milk cartons and shipped to the Starbucks in Azabu, Tokyo.
attributes.title: [9]Takanashi Milk Factory

attributes.description: Narino, Colombia is one of Starbuck’s main supplier of coffee beans. The coffee beans bought from the farms there are used in the Starbucks Roast Coffee Caffe Latte Grande. Starbucks have said that they use fair trade meaning that they do not underpay the workers for the beans. Starbucks have also built a farmer support center in Colombia and have also built 2,000 sanitation facilities and homes in the last few years.
attributes.title: [2]Coffee Bean Farm
[3]Sugar Production
attributes.description: Brasilia, Brazil is the location in which Starbucks buys and uses the sugar in many of their coffees. Brazil is the largest producer of sugar in the world. The sugar canes are grown here and harvested and shipped straight to wherever they need to be.

attributes.title: [6]Coffee Roasting Plant
attributes.description: Washington is one of the many major coffee roasting plants in the US. The coffee beans from South America are shipped here and are roasted. This then goes to Tokyo, Japan to be sold and used there.

attributes.title: [5]Coffee Roasting Plant
attributes.description: South Carolina is one of the many major coffee roasting plants in the US. The coffee beans from South America are shipped here and are roasted. This then goes to Tokyo, Japan to be sold and used there.

attributes.title: [7]Tea Processing Plant
attributes.description: This is where the coffee beans are inspected. Usually, only leaves are transported here to get dried and be able to be used in stores.

attributes.title: [4]Cleaning and Drying The Beans
attributes.description: The coffee beans harvested in Narino, Colombia and dried out in the same location. After 6-14 days of drying in the sun, the coffee beans are shipped to Coffee Roasting Plants in the USA.

attributes.title: [8]Brown Paper Protector
attributes.description: Starbucks have recently started to make brown paper protectors for customers to put around their coffee cups because it may be too hot for them to hold.

attributes.title: [12]Starbucks In Azabu
attributes.description: All of the items and ingredients in order to make the coffee is shipped here to sell to the local people around this Azabu area.

attributes.title: [10]Recycling Cup Factory
attributes.description: This recycling center is where Starbucks cups are made from. Starbucks are pushing for all cups being made from recycled materials at local recycling centers.
